course.course_name: Sustainability and Climate Change in the Arts
course.course_description: Beginning with a consideration of the problem of "nature" in art-historical discourse, this course will explore the emergence of ecological sustainability as a matter of concern among artists from the 1960s through to the early twenty-first century. Special attention will be given to the artistic legacies of Robert Smithson. With Al Gore's An Inconvenient Truth (2006) as an important though problematic point of reference, the second half of the course will be devoted specifically to the ways in which artists, designers, and writers have responded to the planetary crisis of climate change. Overall, the class will ask how this crisis demands a radical rethinking of the role of the arts and humanities within both university research and the public sphere. Many class-sessions will be held on-site at relevant locations and institutions both on the Columbia Campus (The Earth Institute, Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory) and in New York City more generally (The American Museum of Natural History, Central Park, the High Line, Fresh Kills Landfill).

Equivalent to HUMA C1121 and F1121. Not a historical survey but an analytical study of masterpieces, including originals available in the metropolitan area. The chief purpose is to acquaint students with the experience of a work of art. A series of topics in the development of Western art, selected to afford a sense of the range of expressive possibilities in painting, sculpture, and architecture, such as the Parthenon, the Gothic cathedral, and works of Michelangelo, Bruegel, Picasso, and others. Space is limited. Columbia University undergraduates who need this course for graduation are encouraged to register during early registration.

Satisfies the architectural history/theory distribution requirement for majors, but is also open to students wanting a general humanistic approach to architecture and its history. Architecture analyzed through in-depth case studies of major monuments of sacred, public, and domestic space, from the Pantheon and Hagia Sophia to Fallingwater and the Guggenheim.

course.course_name: Deciphering the Past: An Introduction to Paleography and Archival Studies
course.course_description: Framed by an introduction to the principles of Medieval and Renaissance paleography and archival studies, this course gives students an essential training in the transcription and interpretation of manuscript documents from the 15th and 16th centuries. Students will gain hands-on experience with a wide range of Renaissance script styles, several Italian dialects, and the most prevalent document typologies, such as contracts, letters, wills, account books, avvisi and inventories. Special attention will be given to original documents pertaining to notable figures of the Italian Renaissance (including, Leonardo, Savonarola, Machiavelli, Michelangelo) as well as archival case studies (ciphered and coded letters, war correspondence, poison and alchemical recipes).&nbsp; Though students will be mostly working with documents digitized by the Medici Archive Project, classes include scheduled visits to NYC libraries where Italian Renaissance manuscripts will be examined first hand. Designed for students in art history, this course is also suitable for scholars &#8213; including advanced undergraduates &#8213;of any discipline pertaining to the Italian Renaissance and for those who can apply these skills to more modern periods in history. Good command of the Italian language is essential.

course.course_name: Imagery and Form In the Arts
course.course_points_notes: Please attend the first day of class if interested. No application required.
course.course_points_cooked: 4 pts. Please attend the first day of class if interested. No application required.
course.course_description: The operation of imagery and form in dance, music, theatre, visual arts, and writing; students are expected to do original work in one of these arts. Concepts in contemporary art will be explored.

class.class_name: IMAGERY AND FORM IN THE A

course.course_description: An introduction to the arts of China, from the Neolithic period to the present, stressing materials and processes of bronze casting, the development of representational art, principles of text illustration, calligraphy, landscape painting, imperial patronage, and the role of the visual arts in elite culture.

Introduction to the painting, sculpture, and architecture of Japan from the Neolithic period through the 19th century. Discussion focuses on key monuments within their historical and cultural contexts.

Introduction to the painting, sculpture, and architecture of Japan from the Neolithic period through the 19th century. Discussion focuses on key monuments within their historical and cultural contexts.

A survey of the multifaceted forms of Japanese painting from antiquity through the early modern period. major themes to be considered include: painting as an expression of faith; the interplay indigenous and imported pictorial paradigms; narrative and decorative traditions; the emergence of individual artistic agency; the rise of woodblock prints and their impact on European painting in the nineteenth century.

Introduction to the arts of Africa, including masquerading, figural sculpture, reliquaries, power objects, textiles, painting, photography, and architecture. The course will establish a historical framework for study, but will also address how various African societies have responded to the process of modernity
Developed collaboratively and taught digitally spanning one thousand years of architecture.

course.course_name: Medieval Art II: Romanesque and Gothic
course.course_description: This lecture course is intended for students with little or no background in medieval art.  It provides an introduction to a period of one thousand years (fourth to fourteenth centuries) employing a dialectical interaction between memories of the imperial past and the dynamic, forward-moving force of “Gothic.”  We will survey all aspects of artistic production, with especial emphasis upon architecture and monumental sculpture.  In the last part of the term we will turn to some of the principal themes of medieval art, focusing upon objects accessible to the students in the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Cloisters.
Introduction to the art and architecture of the Greek world during the archaic, classical, and Hellenistic periods (11th - 1st centuries B.C.E.).
The architecture, sculpture, and painting of ancient Rome from the 2nd century B.C. to the end of the Empire in the West.

course.course_name: The Archaeology of Death in Ancient Rome
course.course_description: This course serves as a general introduction to the commemoration of death in Roman funerary monuments, giving particular attention to the social bonds they were meant to express and reinforce through visual modes of address.  Memorials dedicated by a socially diverse group of patrons including both elites and non-elites, metropolitan Romans and far-flung provincials, will be studied in relation to an equally diverse body of material evidence including tomb architecture and cemetery planning, inscriptions, sarcophagi and cinerary urns, and portraiture.  The course will also take advantage of sites in New York City such as Greenwood Cemetery and GrantÂ’s Tomb as important points of comparison with the ancient material, as well as the rich collections of the Greek and Roman galleries at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

course.course_name: Early Christian Rome - A Capital in Transition
course.course_description: This course will deal with the origins of Christian art in Rome, a city in search of a new identity from the second to fifth century. It will examine early Christian texts that discuss art as well as catacombs, sarcophagi, murals, mosaics and the earliest examples of sacred architecture in the city.  It will assess the relationship between these various forms of material culture and Judaic and Greco-Roman precedents, and trace their spread from the private to the public sphere. It will also analyze the impact of mass conversion on Rome's topography in the fourth century and the ways in which art helped give shape to the history of the primitive church, its persecution, and ultimate triumph. In essence, the course will investigate how Christian art changed from being a discreet signifier of a marginal sect to an ideological tool and guarantor of Rome's continuing primacy.

course.course_name: Art In China, Japan, and Korea
course.course_description: Introduces distinctive aesthetic traditions of China, Japan, and Korea--their similarities and differences--through an examination of the visual significance of selected works of painting, sculpture, architecture, and other arts in relation to the history, culture, and religions of East Asia.

course.course_name: Masterpieces of Indian Art and Architecture
course.course_description: An introduction to 2000 years of art on the Indian subcontinent. The course covers the early art of Buddhism, rock-cut architecture of the Buddhists and Hindus, the development of the Hindu temple, Mughal and Rajput painting and architecture, art of the colonial period, and the emergence of the Modern.

course.course_name: Masterpieces of Indian Art and Architecture
course.course_description: Introduction to 2000 years of art on the Indian subcontinent. The course covers the early art of Buddhism, rock-cut architecture of the Buddhists and Hindus, the development of the Hindu temple, Mughal and Rajput painting and architecture, art of the colonial period, and the emergence of the Modern.

course.course_name: The Creation of a Visual Culture: Early Islamic Art and Architecture
course.course_description: What is /Islamic Art/?  For a field as chronologically and geographically wide as /Islamic Art/ it is important to begin by questioning the parameters we impose upon the material. The aesthetic, which has been described as /Islamic/, is thought by some to be a conscious construct, by others to be an unjust grouping of diverse visual cultures. This class serves as both an introduction to the field of Islamic art history and as a challenge to its definition. It questions whether we should define art by its maker, its user, or by the notion of inherent style. Readings, lectures and discussions are organized thematically around major monuments and questions of the field. Each class consists of a lecture that presents new material and in-depth visual analysis and discussions wherein students are expected to connect their critical reading of assigned texts to the presented visual material.  Students will be encouraged to investigate the ways in which cultural identity is made visual, or visualized in text, and how this operates within and beyond a specific historical context.

course.course_name: Politics, Piety & Patronage in Late Gothic Art
course.course_description: This course will cover the arts (with an emphasis on sculptural ensembles) in France, England and the Holy Roman Empire from the death of Louis IX in 1270 to the mid-fifteenth century. We will investigate the ways in which patronage, whether royal, clerical or bourgeois, drove artistic programs and stylistic developments. We will also consider the often intertwined roles of piety and politics in the commissioning of works of art. Themes examined include artistic rivalries among various European courts, female patronage, the idea of the portrait, the rise of the individual artist, and developments in devotional and secular luxury arts. Students will take advantage of the wealth of material in local museums and will conduct and present research on objects from this time period in the Metropolitan Museum of Art and The Cloisters.

course.course_name: Imagination & Fantasy in Northern Renaissance Art
course.course_description: This course offers a foundational knowledge of artists, genres, techniques, works, and comprehensive context(s) of the Northern Renaissance through the investigation of canonical works of art. Simultaneously, by raising issues related to imagination and fantasy vis-à-vis the more traditional conventions, new interpretive possibilities for seminal works -- such as Jan van Eyck's Ghent Altarpiece -- will be considered. Students will be encouraged to take advantage of the collections in New York City, and study firsthand many of the works discussed. There are no prerequisites for this course.

course.course_name: Dance and the Early Modern Artist
course.course_description: From an interdisciplinary point of view, this course investigates the representation of dance in Early Modern art.  Using case studies of canonical works by artists such as Donatello, Botticelli, Raphael, Bruegel, Poussin, and Degas, we will examine images that exhibit both explicit and implicit depictions of dance.  From this point of departure, we will ask why the performing arts exert such a force upon how we experience and interpret a wide range of figures and figural compositions.  More specific questions will arise in relationship to the following themes: the impact of Antiquity, the simultaneous rise of art and dance theory, the representation of music and time, parallels between composition and choreography, the concept of grace, dance and religion, the depiction of violence, and the modern viewerÂ’s informative eye.  Ultimately, the class aims to nurture a productive exchange between students from different departments, as well as foster the potential for pushing interdisciplinary study to its limits.  Lectures, discussions, and readings will be complemented by trips to museums, libraries, and performances.

course.course_name: Donatello and the Development of Renaissance Sculpture
course.course_description: Examines the evolution of form and style for sculpture in fifteenth century Florence beginning with the career and technical struggles of Donatello and those involved with his workshop. Consideration of individual projects and of their relationship over the course of time will finally see results in the early works of the young Michelangelo. Students will have the opportunity to identify and develop their own research project, taking advantage of the wealth of primary source and documentary material that survives from the period, its artists, and major patrons such as the Medici family.

course.course_name: From Leonardo to Michelangelo: forming the Renaissance
course.course_description: Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo were of different generations and of different genius, but their mutual coincidence of time and place--a moment in history--all but defined an epoch. Their individual contributions to the development of painting, sculpture, and architecture will be studied both within the broader context of an emerging Renaissance, as well within the much narrower arena--Florence in 1504--where their lives and art intersected.  Students will have the opportunity to identify and develop their own research project, taking advantage of the wealth of surviving objects, primary sources and documentary material.

course.course_name: From Leonardo to Michelangelo: Forming the Renaissance
course.course_description: Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo were of different generations and of different genius, but their mutual coincidence of time and place--a moment in history--all but defined an epoch. Their individual contributions to the development of painting, sculpture, and architecture are studied both within the broader context of an emerging Renaissance, as well within the much narrower arena--Florence in 1504--where their lives and art intersected. This is an introductory course on the early Renaissance in Florence. For an advanced course on a related subject, see Art History S3933Q, below.

course.course_name: Windows to the Soul: Portraiture and Identity in the Renaissance
course.course_description: How can the modern viewer interpret the visual clues that defined identities in the past? Portraits were highly valued during the Renaissance: they were tokens of friendship, expressions of power, proof of artistic skill, and proxies in marriage negotiations.  This course focuses on the development of portraiture in Italy and Northern Europe during the 15th and 16th centuries.   We will examine the concept of self with respect to both sitter and artist, and discuss how various kinds of portraits define and communicate identity. There will be opportunities to examine firsthand the portraits in NY collections.

course.course_name: Rembrandt and Vermeer: The Golden Age of Dutch Art in New York Collections
course.course_description: New York City contains some of the world's most significant collections ofseventeenth-century Dutch art, including major works by both Rembrandt and Vermeer. This course will examine the works of these two masters, their contrasting approaches and theoretical concerns, issues of connoisseurship and collecting, and the cultural and artistic milieu in which they worked. Emphasis will be placed on works in New York collections, and field trips will be made to the Frick Collection, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and the Morgan Library.

course.course_name: Primitivism in Paris from the Guillotine to Picasso
course.course_description: Ever since the landmark exhibition"'Primitivism' and 20th Century Art" held at the Museum of Modern Art in New York (1984), the term Primitivism has primarily come to signify the appropriation of so-called "primitive" art from Africa, Oceania and the Americas by Modernist artists: This course investigates the protean nature of Primitivism through texts and images ranging across disciplines and media. We will trace the various strategies of constructing the "other" through lithography, photography, museum displays and painting, ending with an in-depth examination of Picasso's canonical Desmoiselles d'Avignon at MoMA. Combining art history with diverse literary texts, "scientific" treatises on race, and anthropological accounts, this course will deepen knowledge of the phenomenon of "primitivism" by considering the continuities and ruptures in strategies of pictorial "othering" from the nineteenth to the early twentieth centuries. Case studies will offer competing definitions of what was deemed to be "primitive" at different moments isolating major themes including: the duality of the term "primitive" used as praise and critique, relationship between center and periphery, the concomitant formulation of Nationalism and Colonialism, biological models and stylistic development, the interdependence of science and culture, and finally strategies of display in museums and private collections. This course presents opportunities to engage seminal works by Picasso and Gauguin in a new light but will also give students the chance to discover lesserknown treasures of medieval art at the Cloisters Museum and Library and provide a rare opportunity to visit a distinguished private collection of African art. Through these trajectories we will see that before Gauguin started painting Tahitian women on burlap sacks and Picasso first encountered African "fetishes" in a dusty museum, Primitivism already had a long history.

course.course_name: Paris, Cultural Capital in the Middle Ages [in English]

course.course_description: The course examines selected topics in the history of European painting from the 1780s to 1900. It will explore a range of aesthetic, cultural and social issues through the work of major figures from David, Goya, and Turner to Manet, Seurat and Cezanne. This is a no laptop, no e-device course.

course.course_name: On the Streets of New York: Architectural and Cultural History of the City
course.course_description: The built environment of New York has always been more than a collection of physical objects; it has become a set of cultural narratives. A building or a neighborhood might inspire artworks, or claim a social significance far beyond its utilitarian function. This course will survey the history of the physical city of New York as it shaped and was shaped by the city's cultural history. We will discuss the city's archtectural history, and the ways in which buildings and streets reflect the cultural aspirations of their builders. Above all, the course will focus on the lived city, how New York has been experienced over time from the sidewalks. In addition to meeting in the classroom, we will take serveral field trips throughout New York City.

course.course_name: American Art in thhe Gilded Age
course.course_description: From the mid-Nineteenth Century until WWI, New York was at the center of "Gilded Age" culture. Vanderbilt, Frick, Morgan and other "robber barons" built mansions, art collections, and other monuments to their fortunes in the city, while on the other end of the social spectrum a host of "popular" arts gained vitality as new audiences populated urban centers such as New York.  Aesthetic interiors, carefully composed out of Tiffany glass, paintings by Whistler, Sargent and William Merit Chase, imported textiles and elaborate architectural detail coexisted  - almost side by side, with Nickolodeons, dime museums, and the Lower East Side slums made infamous in the photographs of Jacob Riis, which promised to reveal "How the Other Half Lives." In class and on site visits, we will explore and examine the conflicts and contrasts that characterize American society in this era. We'll visit the Frick and the Morgan Collections, both virtually intact repositories of past opulence, as well as the Metropolitan Museum of art, whose foundation was meant, in part, to bring disparate groups together through art.   A few key literary sources, from authors such as Mark Twain, Edith Wharton, and William Dean Howells will bring the period to life in some of its greatest works of fiction in which art, design and architecture often function as major characters.

course.course_name: Jackson Pollock and the NY School
course.course_description: Coming on the heels of the MoMA's blockbuster exhibit, this seminar will trace the rise and fall of Abstract Expressionism, from its pre-World War II precipitates in Europe (Surrealism) and in America (Regionalism), to the crucial moment when, as scholar Serge Guilbaut has argued, New York "stole" the idea of modern art, and finally, through the decade when Pop Art rendered Abstract Expressionism obsolete. Although special emphasis will be given to Jackson Pollock, whose persona and work reside at the literal and figurative center of the movement, we will also look closely at works by Mark Rothko, Clyfford Still, Willem DeKooning, Lee Krasner, Louise Bourgeois, Helen Frankenthaler, Eva Hesse, Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns and Cy Twombly.  Class lectures and presentations will be supplemented with trips to New York's world-renowned museums.

course.course_name: Twentieth Century Architecture and City Planning
course.course_description: This undergraduate lecture course is an introduction to the crucial and peculiar topics in the history of modern (western) architecture of the twentieth century. The course does not systematically cover all the major events, ideas, protagonists, and buildings of the period. It is organized around thematic and sometimes monographic lectures, which are intended to represent the very essential character of modern architecture from its beginnings around 1900 until some more recent developments at the end of the century.

course.course_name: Art, Design, and the American Social Imaginary
course.course_description: This seminar will investigate the way American notions of democratic interaction have been changed by developments in communications technology from the mid_19th century to the end of the twentieth century. We will closely examine three key periods: the literary world of the 1840s-50s, the rise of the counterculture movement in the 1950s through the 1960s, and the irruption of multiculturalism, which changed the face of the art world, in the 1990s. The materials of the course are interdisciplinary in nature, and will include literary works like Herman Melville's Bartleby, the Scrivener, works of fine art like the paintings of Willem de Kooning and the images of Kara Walker, radical cultural practices like those of the Black Panthers' designer Emory Douglas and the Occupy movement, and theoretical writings on the nature of expressive agency. From this eclectic selection of materials, students will gain a sense of the enormous diversity of the ways of imagining social life and the corresponding methods of social interaction used by American artists and activists.

Supplemented by museum and gallery visits, this course is an introduction to major trends in European and American art in the twentieth century - from the influence of Post-impressionism on the rise of Fauvism and Cubism, through the interwar avant-gardes, to the impact of Marcel Duchamp on the mass-mediated, serialized and identity-oriented strategies that characterize artistic production since the 1960s - and is intended to help students acquire a knowledge of major artistic movements and artworks throughout the 20th century, together with an awareness of the cultural and social contexts in which they emerged. Students will also develop the analytical and visual skills necessary to interpret and understand the great diversity of artworks and critical theories and positions that constitute the history of Modernism and its others in 20th-century art.

The course will examine a variety of figures, movements, and practices within the entire range of 20th-century art—from Expressionism to Abstract Expressionism, Constructivism to Pop Art, Surrealism to Minimalism, and beyond–situating them within the social, political, economic, and historical contexts in which they arose.  The history of these artistic developments will be traced through the development and mutual interaction of two predominant strains of artistic culture: the modernist and the avant-garde, examining in particular their confrontation with and development of the particular vicissitudes of the century’s ongoing modernization.  Discussion section complement class lectures.  Course is a prerequisite for certain upper-level art history courses.

course.course_name: The Display of Art in New York City 1970s to the Present: Politics, Ideology, and Aesthetics
course.course_description: Through case studies focused around art sites in New York, this course will critically evaluate the multiplicity of contexts in which art works are exhibited and distributedÂ–from museums and galleries, to streets, screens, and printed pages. We will examine museum collection practices; exhibition design and the architecture of display; the relationship between art sites and their surroundings; discipline, spectatorship, and participation; and the politics of artÂ’s accessibility and distribution. These considerations will be part of a larger investigation of how cultural meaning and historical narratives are constructed.  The class will include many on-site discussions at museums; enrolled students will do a fair amount of standing and walking.

course.course_name: Electronic Arts: Paradigms at the Intersection of Art and Technology in the Information Age
course.course_description: In his 1970 text "The Electronic Revolution," William Burroughs envisioned a future in which constant recording allowed for the cutting, remixing, and viral distribution of audio- and video-tape-a seeming premonition of the ubiquity of DIY multimedia in the age of web 2.0. Without eliding important historical and technological differences, we will consider the ways in which the electromagnetic tapes, computer software, and global networks of the electronic revolution-which significantly altered the nature of both information and representation-have been negotiated by art over the last five decades and across media formats, from painting to "bio art" and beyond. Instead of offering an historical survey, the class will be structured around a series of paradigms associated with electronic technologies (e.g., "database," "programming," "virus," etc.); these will serve as platforms for the introduction of topics that span 20th and 21st century art, including the prosthetic extension of human perception, the relationship between reality and representation, and the deployment of art for political ends. We will also consider the ways in which contemporary electronic art engages current debates over government and corporate surveillance, intellectual property rights, global capitalism, and the definition of life. An integral part of this course will be viewing and studying electronic art on exhibit in New York City, which will prepare students for the final project: curating their own virtual exhibition. No pre-requisites are required, but it is highly recommended that students have some prior exposure to 20th century art.

course.course_name: Collage: History of a Concept & Technique
course.course_description: Collage was central to the artistic practice of every major 20th century artist. From Cubism to Feminism, collage defined the evolution of Modernism.  After its initial adoption by Picasso and Braque in 1912, artists as diverse as Kazimir Malevitch, Kurt Schwitters, Hannah Höch, Salvador Dali, Joseph Cornell, Robert Rauschenberg, Robert Motherwell, and Nancy Spero deployed collage--as both a technique and a concept. The Â“pasted papersÂ” were expanded into photomontage, assemblage, and installations, and from the two-dimensional to the three-dimensional.  An investigation of the formal and theoretical innovations and strategies of juxtaposition, fragmentation, and simultaneity of texts and images, of abstraction and figuration, of painting and found objects will give students unique insights into the major Modernist movements, including Cubism, Futurism, Dadaism, Surrealism, Feminism, Pop and Conceptual art.  We will study the theory and practice of collage through in-class slide lectures, first hand viewing of collections in museums and galleries, and reading the critical literature. Students will conduct research based on the wealth of resources and the direct experience of collage.

Focuses on the intersection of photography with traditional artistic practices in the 19th century, on the mass cultural functions of photography in propaganda and advertising from the 1920s onwards, and on the emergence of photography as the central medium in the production of postwar avant-garde art practices.

Photography has undergone several "revolutions" since its early 19th-century origins, not least of which is the advent and enormous popularity of digital photography and the possibilities for experimentation that new cameras and software afford virtually everyone. Through selected case studies, supplemented by museum and gallery visits, this course investigates the major movements, stylistic shifts, and technological developments in photography since 1945. The omnipresent ubiquity of photographic images in contemporary life are examined, as are photography's crossover with post-war painting (in the work of Robert Rauschenberg, Andy Warhol and others).

Few media have shaped the course of modernity more powerfully than photography. Law, science, journalism, criminology, urban planning, and entertainment are but a handful of the fields remade by the introduction of photography. More ambivalent has been photography's relationship to art. Once relegated to the margins, photographic practices now occupy the center of much artistic production. This course will not attempt a comprehensive survey of the medium. Rather, we will trace central developments through a series of case studies from photography's nineteenth century birth to its current, digital afterlife. We will cover seminal movements and figures as well as more obscure practices and discourses. Particular attention will be paid to the theoretical and methodological questions concerning the medium.

Focuses on the intersection of photography with traditional artistic practices in the 19th century, on the mass cultural functions of photography in propaganda and advertising from the 1920s onwards, and on the emergence of photography as the central medium in the production of postwar avant-garde art practices.

Few media have shaped the course of modernity more powerfully than photography. Law, science, journalism, criminology, urban planning, and entertainment are but a handful of the fields remade by the introduction of photography. More ambivalent has been photography's relationship to art. Once relegated to the margins, photographic practices now occupy the center of much artistic production. This course will not attempt a comprehensive survey of the medium. Rather, we will trace central developments through a series of case studies from photography's nineteenth century birth to its current, digital afterlife. We will cover seminal movements and figures as well as more obscure practices and discourses. Particular attention will be paid to the theoretical and methodological questions concerning the medium.

Photography has undergone several "revolutions" since its early 19th-century origins, not least of which is the advent and enormous popularity of digital photography and the possibilities for experimentation that new cameras and software afford virtually everyone. Through selected case studies, supplemented by museum and gallery visits, this course investigates the major movements, stylistic shifts, and technological developments in photography since 1945. The omnipresent ubiquity of photographic images in contemporary life are examined, as are photography's crossover with post-war painting (in the work of Robert Rauschenberg, Andy Warhol and others).

course.course_name: The Art of Objects: Tradition and Innovation in Still Life
course.course_description: A critical survey of the genre of still life from the Renaissance to the twentieth century. Examines the emergence of the independent still life in the sixteenth century and considers its transformation from a Â“minorÂ” genre to a significant category for avant-garde explorations in art. Discussing artists such as Leonardo da Vinci, Caravaggio, Velasquez, Chardin, Goya, Cezanne, Picasso, and Warhol, close attention will be paid to formal innovations, techniques, and the cultural meaning of objects in relation to the still life tradition. In turn, the gendered biases that have informed the practices and reception of still life will be investigated through interventions in this genre by female artists.

At the center of the avant-garde imagination—and the interwar period in Europe more broadly—were photography and film. Long relegated to the margins of art history and rarely studied together, photography and film were often the guiding lights and vehicles for mass dissemination of avant-garde images and techniques. This lecture course delves into interbellum art, photography, film, and critical writing as it surveys a range of avant-garde movements and national cinemas; seminal artists and theorists; and topics such as montage, abstraction, technological media, archives, advertising, sites and architectures of reception. Film screenings will take place most weeks.

course.course_name: The Enchanted World of German Romantic Prints, 1750-1850
course.course_description: The Enchanted World of German Romantic Prints 1770 – 1850 will open in Philadelphia in late 2013 and travel to several venues. Drawn entirely from Philadelphia Museum of Art’s uniquely rich holdings of more than 8,000 prints by 800 German School painters and printmakers of this period, the exhibition will feature 125 works by leading Austrian, German, and Swiss artists working at home and abroad, including Josef Danhauser, Caspar David Friedrich, Ludwig Emil Grimm, Carl Wilhelm Kolbe, Ferdinand Olivier, Johann Christian Reinhart, Ludwig Richter, Karl Friedrich Schinkel, and Philipp Otto Runge, and Adrian Zingg. Spanning eight decades, from the first stirrings of a Romantic sensibility among German-speaking writers and artists in the 1770s to the pan-European uprisings of 1848/49, the selected works mirror many of the sweeping social and political changes that occurred during these turbulent times, reflecting such significant new trends in the arts as the growing appreciation of late Gothic and early Renaissance art – especially Dürer and Raphael – and the widespread enthusiasm for recently rediscovered medieval sagas, age-old fairy tales, popular ballads, and folk songs. The prints of the period document important shifts in taste in contemporary art circles, including the rise to prominence of landscape, informal portraiture, and scenes of everyday life alongside the more highly-ranked academic art categories of history and religion. The exhibition and catalogue will also treat a number of important printmaking innovations, among them the introduction of new technology (lithography and steel engraving) and new methods of print distribution (print albums, illustrated books and almanacs, annual print club editions), all of which served a rapidly expanding world of print collectors made up of a newly flourishing segment of the population, the cultivated citizenry known as the Lesepublikum, or reading public.

In this seminar we will apply the notion of  “mapping,” or spatial databasing to a corpus of English Gothic churches and cathedrals.  We will, in addition, explore the notion of “Englishness” in architectural production of the twelfth to fifteenth centuries.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Cloisters, and the Morgan Library house medieval works of extraordinary interest from a wide range of periods and regions. Taking advantage of this opportunity, the course focuses on selected objects (as case studies) in these local institutions. We will examine medieval buildings, sculptures, reliquaries and manuscripts first-hand, investigating their original context, their later identity as collection pieces, and their place within the broader cultural background of art and architecture from Late Antiquity to the Gothic.

This course examines the critical approaches to contemporary art from the 1970s to the present.  It will address a range of historical and theoretical issues around the notion of “the contemporary” (e.g. globalization, participation, relational art, ambivalence, immaterial labor) as it has developed in the era after the postmodernism of the 1970s and 1980s.
course.prerequisites: Approval of instructor, 20th Century Art recommended.

course.course_name: Japan and the World in 19th-Century Art
course.course_description: Examines the late 19th to early 20th-century Western interest in things Japanese and its relation to artistic production, collecting, and appreciation in Japan and in the West. Critical analysis of primary sources is accompanied by discussion of historical context, including the worldÂ’s fairs, and the exploration of different methodological perspectives.

course.course_name: Majors' Colloquium: the Literature and Methods of Art History
course.course_description: Introduction to different methodological approaches to the study of art and visual culture. Majors are encouraged to take the colloquium during their junior year.
course.prerequisites: the department's permission. Students must sign-up in 826 Schermerhorn.
course.course_instructors_actual: J. Crary, N. Elcott, Z. Bahrani
course.course_instructors_full: J. Crary, N. Elcott, Z. Bahrani

course.course_name: Black West: African American Artists in the Western United States
course.course_description: This course considers the creative production of African Americans primarily in California in the 19th and 20th centuries. Themes pertinent to the course include: how are African American identities and cultural production imbricated with concepts of what is considered “western” or trends of west coast artmaking?; what can these artists tell us about notions of space, place, and migration in the African American imagination?

class.class_name: AFR AM ARTISTS IN THE US

course.course_description: Every picture tells a story, but how, exactly, do fixed images present narrative information? This undergraduate seminar will examine artworks from diverse cultures and time periods to investigate the various strategies employed by visual artists to suggest temporal progressions of events. This course is open to all students who have previously taken Art Humanities or its equivalent; while we will be considering issues related to narrative content in static visual media, Literature and Film Studies majors with an interest in literary or cinematic narrative are also encouraged to enroll.

This seminar will explore, through the selection of a limited number of works of art and architecture, the rich artistic traditions of Latin America. The structure of the course will be generally chronological, beginning with an examination of the art of certain pre-Columbian cultures, followed by an exploration of the art of both the colonial period and the period of independence, and concluding with the Modernist movement and works of contemporary art. Although the courseÂ’s geographical and historical reach is large (spanning over 5,000 years of history and the larger part of an entire content) and the works that we will examine are selective rather than comprehensive, certain recurring themes of current scholarship will be the basis of class discussions. Such themes include the effect of European contact upon existing and emerging art styles in the Americas, the beneficial and problematic associations of the term Â“Latin AmericaÂ”, and the role of art in defining a cultural or national identity. Class discussions, museum visits and assigned readings are intended to help students in the critical evaluation of this art.
This seminar explores the issues of art and sacrfice in the Aztec empire from the points of view of the 16th century and modern times.
Explores various ways in which the West has made sense of Andean Art from the 16th century to the present.

course.course_name: The Public Monument in the Ancient Near East
course.course_description: This seminar will focus on the invention of the public monument as a commemorative genre, and the related concepts of time, memory and history in the ancient Near East and Egypt. Public monuments will be studied in conjunction with readings from ancient texts (in translation), as well as historical criticism, archaeological and art historical theories.

course.course_name: Lorenzo the Magnificent and His Artists
course.course_description: Examines the artistic commissions of Lorenzo deï¿½Medici at the height of his ascendancy in 15th-century Florence, with a mind to both individual projects and as they relate to each other over the course of time. Students have the opportunity to identify and develop their own research project, taking advantage of the wealth of primary source and documentary material that survives from the period, its artists, and the Medici family. An advanced course. For an introductory course on a related subject, see AHIS S3437Q, above.

course.course_name: The Formation of Great Art Collections in New York
course.course_description: This seminar, made possible by the Center for the History of Collecting in America at the Frick Collection and Frick Art Reference Library, will examine the motives, methods, and history of collectors based in New York during the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries.  Classes will be held both at Columbia and on site at The Frick Collection and other museums that have grown and flourished as a result of private art collecting. Ideally, students should have a strong background in art history and/or cultural history to fully benefit from this interdisciplinary approach to art.

This course is an introduction to postwar American and European art for undergraduates. Emphasis on the internal relationships among major trends in the American avant-garde throughout the 1950s and 1960s (from Abstract Expressionism through Neo-Dada and Pop to Minimalism); the rise of Conceptual Art in the 1960s and 1970s, focusing on the increasingly uncertain status of the art object, as well as how postwar artists importantly critiqued and often resisted traditional venues for its display and exhibition; and, finally, the rise of Postmodernism, identity politics and Globalization in the last decades of the millennium.  The course includes museum and gallery trips.

Selected readings in 19th-century philosophy, literature and art criticism with emphasis on problems of modernity and aesthetic experience. Texts include work by Diderot, Kant, Coleridge, Hegel, Emerson, Flaubert, Ruskin, Baudelaire, and Nietzsche.
course.prerequisites: Junior or senior standing and the instructor's permission.

course.course_name: The Art of Witness: Memorials and Historical Trauma
course.course_description: Attendance at the first class is mandatory. Limited to 15 students. Instructor determines class roster on first day of class. Examines aesthetic responses to collective historical traumas, such as slavery, the Holocaust, the bombing of Hiroshima, AIDS, homelessness, immigration, and the recent attack on the World Trade Center.

This course explores the relation between the creative process and the respective conditions of expatriation, emigration and exile from the beginning of the French Revolution in 1789 until the end of the Bourbon Restoration in 1830. While all three conditions involve distance from one's home, the personal and historical factors that define them varied significantly, with corresponding differences in the way that the creative process was approached. Examining the cases of Élisabeth Vigée-Lebrun, Jacques-Louis David and Francisco de Goya among others, this course focuses on the works artists produced while away from their native land, often by constraint rather than choice. Topics of discussion include: the Grand Tour and cosmopolitanism circa 1789; the category of the émigré(e)-artist; Revolution, gender and exile; uprooting and creative paralysis/creative fury; the refashioning of artistic identity; and the relation to history and the recent past.

course.course_name: Sacred Love in Italian Renaissance Art
course.course_description: What is the nature of sacred love? How is it different from love experienced within romance, marriage, and friendship? How does one love God? What role does art play in conceptualizing divine love? How does it stimulate desire in the viewer’s soul, mind, and body? Such questions structure this course’s investigation of sacred love in Italian Renaissance art. The course examines religious art created between 1250-1550 within the cities of Florence, Venice, Rome, Siena, and Mantua, while simultaneously exploring the changing theological notions of love from the late medieval period through the Counter-Reformation. Topics covered within the course include the adoration of Jesus’ body in the altarpiece; devotion in the context of Madonna and Child paintings; ecstatic transcendence in portrayals of saints like St. Mary Magdalene and St. Catherine of Siena; holy matrimony within the convent and monastery; as well as charity in the art of confraternities dedicated to amor dei and amor proximi.

course.course_name: Sacred Love in Italian Renaissance Art
course.course_description: What is the nature of sacred love? How is it different from love experienced within romance, marriage, and friendship? How does one love God? What role does art play in conceptualizing divine love? How does it stimulate desire in the viewer's soul, mind, and body? Such questions structure this course's investigation of sacred love in Italian Renaissance art. The course examines religious art created between 1250-1550 within the cities of Florence, Venice, Rome, Siena, and Mantua, while simultaneously exploring the changing theological notions of love from the late medieval period through the Counter-Reformation. Topics covered within the course include the adoration of Jesus' body in the altarpiece; devotion in the context of Madonna and Child paintings; ecstatic transcendence in portrayals of saints like St. Mary Magdalene and St. Catherine of Siena; holy matrimony within the convent and monastery; as well as charity in the art of confraternities dedicated to amor dei and amor proximi.

This course traces the history of printmaking in the Western world from the fifteenth to the twentieth centuries. The class will focus on major individual contributions (ranging from the works of Albrecht Durer to those of Andy Warhol), and numerous techniques, while also considering significant thematic questions. Visits to the Metropolitan Museum and Butler Library will allow students to engage in a hands-on analysis of various prints' techniques and styles.
Independent research and the writing of an essay under supervision of a member of the Art History Department. Only one independent study may be counted toward the major.
course.prerequisites: the permission of the departmental consultant or director of undergraduate studies and of the instructor.
course.course_instructors_actual: B. Bergdoll, B. Joseph, C. Grewe, D. Delbanco, D. Freedberg, E. Pasztory, F. Benelli, F. de Angelis, H. Klein, I. Mylonopoulos, J. Crary, J. Rajchman, K. Cabanas, K. Jones, M. Cole, M. McKelway, N. Elcott, R. Harrist, R. Krauss, S. Murray, V. Dehejia, V. Di Palma, Z. Bahrani, Z. Strother
course.course_instructors_full: B. Bergdoll, B. Joseph, C. Grewe, D. Delbanco, D. Freedberg, E. Pasztory, F. Benelli, F. de Angelis, H. Klein, I. Mylonopoulos, J. Crary, J. Rajchman, K. Cabanas, K. Jones, M. Cole, M. McKelway, N. Elcott, R. Harrist, R. Krauss, S. Murray, V. Dehejia, V. Di Palma, Z. Bahrani, Z. Strother

course.course_description: Instructor permission required. Enrollment limited to 15. Factors involved in judging works of art, with emphasis on paintings; materials; technique, condition, attribution; identification of imitations and fakes; questions of relative quality.
course.prerequisites: Please see Barnard College Art History department Web site for instructions.

course.course_name: Art on the Move: Issues in Cultural Property
course.course_description: This course examines what happens when art crosses borders between cultures. We will look at the historical development of motivations for taking the art of different cultures, from war-time revenge to aesthetic appreciation to scholarly acquisitions. Using case studies, we will determine the effect of these takings on the source culture, and consider the wide range of ethical dilemmas faced by those who have taken art, including preservation, presentation, and interpretation. The last part of the class is dedicated to the examination of current concerns in the field of cultural property: the effects of the modern marketplace for art without provenance and the protection of the art of indigenous cultures. We will see these debates in practice during trips to New York museums. Students will be evaluated on the basis of participation and a final paper and presentation.
Required for all thesis writers.
Prerequisite: GSAS G4008.  Practicum in archival management; preparation of a substantial inventory (160 hours).  Past topic:   producing inventories for components or units of Malcolm X papers.
Archival theory and practice; optional 50-hour practicum.
Survey of the arts of sub-Saharan Africa.

course.course_name: Art and Archaeology of West Africa
course.course_description: Reviews the history of West African art from circa 500 B.C.E. through 1900 C.E., using mostly evidence from sculpture, pottery, and textiles. Also critically assesses the current state of archaeological research and its value to art historical scholarship.

A survey of the major pre-Hispanic cities of Mexico and Guatemala, including San Lorenzo, Teotihuacan, Tikal, Monte Alban, Uxmal, and Chichen Itza. Aesthetic, historical, and archaeological problems are discussed.
Survey of the art of the Andes from earliest times until the Spanish conquest. Emphasis on the nature of Andean tradition and the relationship between art and society.
Survey of the paintings of the Edo period from the 17th to the 19th centuries, with emphasis on the development of the various schools of the period

course.course_name: Vision and Imagination in Chinese Painting
Chinese Painting of the Ming Dynasty
course.course_description: Topics include regional centers of painting, painting in the context of social and economic history and urbanization, art collecting, and art theory.  Special emphasis on the painters Dai Jin, Shen Zhou, Qiu Ying, and Dong Qichang.

course.course_name: Chinese Painting of the Northern Song Period
course.course_description: An examination of the major genres of painting with special emphasis on landscape, imperial patronage, texts on painting, relationships between painting and urban life, and the rise of the scholar-artist tradition.

course.course_name: Chinese Painting of the Qing Dynasty
course.course_description: Topics include painting at the imperial court, Chinese encounters with Western pictorial art, painting Yangzhou and other urban centers, and painting in Shanghai during the 19th century.  Special emphasis on the painters Shih-t’ao, Lang Shining (G. Castiglione), Jin Nong, and Ren Xiong.

course.course_name: Chinese Painting of the Southern Song Period
course.course_description: An examination of painting at the imperial court, with special emphasis on the relationship between words and images, the relationship between the environment of Hangzhou and landscape representations, genre painting, and the rise of Chan Buddhist painting.

course.course_name: Early Chinese Painting: Han Through Tang
course.course_description: The early history of Chinese painting, with special emphasis on art produced for tombs, narrative illustration, Buddhist painting, imperial patronage, and the beginnings of art theory and criticism in China.

course.course_name: Art and Architecture of the Heian and Kamakura Periods
course.course_description: A survey of Buddhist arts and architecture from the 11th through the 13th centuries.

Surveys the history and development of the folding-screen format in Japanese painting from the 8th to 17th centuries. Through a series of case studies, explores art historical issues for which the folding screen provides a unique perspective, including the relationships between painting and architectural space, poetic practice, religious ritual.

course.course_name: Medieval Art I: From Late Antiquity to the End of Byzantium
course.course_description: A survey of Early Christian and Byzantine art from its origins in the eastern provinces of the Late Roman Empire through the Ottoman Conquest of Constantinople in 1453. The course is first segment of a two-part survey of medieval monuments offered by the Department of Art History and Archaeology.

Introduction to the art and architecture of Mesopotamia beginning with the establishment of the first cities in the fourth millennium B.C.E. through the fall of Babylon to Alexander of Macedon in the fourth century B.C.E. Focus on the distinctive concepts and uses of art in the Assyro-Babylonian tradition.

course.course_name: The Art of Mesopotamia: 4th To 2nd Millenium B.C.E
course.course_description: Introduction to ancient Near Eastern art as it developed on the background of the political and social changes from the earliest known urban civilization to territorial states.  Questions of (dis-)continuity in the visual representation of gods or political rulers and in the selection of narrative scenes on seals, reliefs, in statues and terracottas are discussed in relation to ideological, ethnical, social and economical differences.

course.course_name: Art and Architecture of Ancient Assyria
course.course_description: Survey of the art and architecture of ancient Assyria (northern Iraq) from the Early Dynastic period (ca. 2500 B.C.E.) until the end of the Neo-Assyrian empire (612 B.C.E.).  Surviving artifacts, excavation reports, ancient written records, and specialized studies on trade, state and imperial administration, cult and temple, history, and language.

An examination of the arts, architecture, and archaeology of the Aegean, inclusive of surrounding eastern and western Mediterranean regions, this survey includes material from the Bronze Age, with a particular focus on the visual culture of the Minoans and Mycenaeans.
The development of medieval art in the Germanic kingdoms of western Europe from the mid-7th century to the end of the Carolingian empire
Prerequisite: one introductory course in medieval art.  The role of monumental art in the transformation of imperial Rome into the capital of Western Christendom between the 4th and 14th centuries.
Origins and development of French Gothic painting from the Ingeborg Psalter through the works of Pucelle and his circle.

From the transformation of Rayonnant Gothic architecture in the latter part of the 13th century to an exploration of 14th- and 15th-century architecture organized on a regional basis, with emphasis upon France, England and Germany.
A survey of Renaissance Architecture in Italy through its buildings and its theory, from Brunelleschi to Palladio and the influence to other European country.

course.course_name: Italian Renaissance Architecture From Brunelleschi To Michelangelo
course.course_description: The work of Brunelleschi, Alberti, Leonardo, Bramante, Raphael, the Sangallos, Sansovino, Michelangelo and Palladio, integrated into the study of urban history, villas and gardens, liturgy, war and fortifications, palace culture and perspective. Frequent use of rare materials in Avery Library.

course.course_name: Italian Baroque Architecture: Michelangelo To Piranesi
course.course_description: The protagonists of baroque architecture in Rome, Piedmont, Naples and Sicily. Emphasis on the history of urban planning, garden design, and the evolution of the architectural profession.

course.course_preface: This course will be held in Venice, Italy.
course.course_description: This is a summer session 2005 course available through the School of Continuing Education. The course will be held in Venice.

course.course_name: Florentine Sculpture From Donatello To Michelangelo
course.course_description: The origins of Renaissance sculpture in Florence, beginning with the competition of 1401 for the Baptistry doors. The art of Donatello, Ghiberti Desiderio, Bernardo Rosselino, Verrocchio, Antonio Pollaiuolo, Benedetto da Maiano and Michelangelo examined in detail.

course.course_name: From the Gothic to the Antique: Michelangelo & the Sculptural Tradition
course.course_description: Beginning with the works of Nicola Pisano and the Gothic tradition in Tuscany, we will consider the evolution of form and style as produced by the sculptors in the generations before Michelangelo.  In addition to these many remnants of the recent medieval past, objects from antiquity survived and were preserved in ever increasing quantities in private collections, such as the Mediciï¿½s, as well as in less private settings such as churches.  Ultimately the complex of these varied types and styles formed the basis of the personal style developed by the young Michelangelo.  Students will have the opportunity to identify and develop their own research project, taking advantage of the wealth of primary source and documentary material that survives from the period, its artists, and major patrons.

This course will focus on the figurative arts in both southern and northern Europe between the fourteenth and early sixteenth centuries. Making ample use of the early Rejlaissance collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Frick, and the Pierpont Morgan, as well as several special exhibitions to be held in the summer of2012 (North Italian Paintings from the Accademia Carrara, Bergamo and Durer and Beyond: Central European Drawings in the Metropolitan Museum of Art 1400-1700 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art; Antico: The Golden Age of Renaissance Bronzes at the Frick Collection), the course will examine painting, sculpture, and the decorative arts in Italy, the Netherlands, France, and Germany before the Protestant Reformation with an eye for both the commonalities (Christianity, classical heritage) that bound these various regions and the differences that nurtured dynamic cultural exchange. The material will be organized thematically, with sessions dedicated to examining iconographic themes and conventions across geographic and cultural borders. Special attention will be paid to the visualization of texts (Old and New Testaments, apocrypha, hagiography, classical mythology, etc.), and representations of the ancient, medieval, or non-European world. By studying Renaissance art across the continent rather than solely in Italy or the Netherlands, students will gain a better sense of how artistic forms, iconography, and actual works of art traveled between north and south, through the agency of pilgrims, literary texts, diplomatic missions, trade, manual copies, and prints, as well as how this exchange of cultural capital fed into artistic accomplishments of the High Renaissance.

course.course_name: Byzantine Art From Justinian To the Palaeologan Renaissance
course.course_description: The major patrons and themes in the art of the Byzantine (East Roman) empire from the 6th to 14th centuries.  Topics to be examined include the patronage of Justinian, the theology of icons, the classical system of Byzantine church decoration, the concept of renaissance in the middle Byzantine period and the question of provincial Byzantine art.

course.course_name: Art In the Age of Reformation
course.course_description: Artistic production in Germany and the Netherlands in the 16th century and the transformation of the social function of art as a consequence of the development of reformed theories of art and the introduction of humanist culture: Albrecht Dï¿½rer, Hans Baldung Grien, Hans Holbein the Younger, Albrecht Altdorfer, Quentin Massys, Lucas van Leyden, Jan Gossaert, Jan van Hemessen, and Pieter Aertsen.

course.course_name: Art In the Age of Reformation
course.course_description: Artistic production in Germany and the Netherlands in the 16th century and the transformation of the social function of art as a consequence of the development of reformed theories of art and the introduction of humanist culture: Albrecht Dï¿½rer, Hans Baldung Grien, Hans Holbein the Younger, Albrecht Altdorfer, Quentin Massys, Lucas van Leyden, Jan Gossaert, Jan van Hemessen, and Pieter Aertsen.
Emphasis is placed on such masters as Poussin, Claude, La Tour, the Le Nains, Le Brun, and on the development of French classicism and academic theory.
A study of architecture, urban planning, and theory between the reigns of Francois I and Louis XIV.

course.course_name: Image and Idea in Romanesque and Gothic art
course.course_description: Romanesque and Gothic art and architecture from about 1000 to the Renaissance. Emphasis on key monuments and their roles in the evolution of style, iconography, and metaphysical ideas.

course.course_name: European Cities and the Discourses of Urban Planning, 1750-1890
course.course_description: Prerequisite: for undergraduates, a course in modern architecture. The rise of modern town planning theory from the Enlightenment critiques of Voltaire, Laugier, and Pierre Patte to the reappraisal of organic city form by Camillo Sitte. In addition to ideal, the course will focus on the transformation of four European capitals: London, Paris, Berlin, and Vienna.

course.course_name: Tradition & Innovation In German Architecture: Schinkel, Semper, Mies
course.course_description: Prerequisite for undergraduates: course in 19th or 20th century architectural history and instructor's permission. Discussion sections for undergraduates to be arranged. German Architectural design and theory from Winckelmann to the early work of Mies van der Rohe with special emphasis on Schinkel and his contemporaries in Prussia, Bavaria, and Baden. Key texts of architectural theory and contemporary literary or philosophical theories that shaped architectural thought.

Starting with the various trends which can be distinguished in Flemish art in the early 16th century, traces the development of painting in Flanders to the middle of the 17th century, with special emphasis on Bruegel and Rubens.

course.course_name: Dutch and Flemish Painting From Bruegel To Rembrandt
course.course_description: A survey of the principal painters active in the Netherlands from ca. 1560 to ca. 1670. Special attention to Bruegel, van Dyck, and Rubens; to Goltzius, Rembrandt, and Vermeer; and to the most important painters of landscape and genre.

course.course_name: 17th-Century Painting In the Netherlands: the Problem of Realism
course.course_description: A survey of genre and landscape painting from the point of view of old and new interpretations. The issues of realism, notional accuracy, and selectivity are assessed, while the merits of the newer iconographic and symbolic approaches are examined. Genre painters will range from Dou to Steen and Vermeer; landscape painters from Esaias van de Velde to Rembrandt and Jacob van Ruisdael.

Architectural theory, beginning with Claude Perrault in the 17th century and continuing through to J.-B. Rondelet and J.-N.-L. Durand in the early 19th century, related directly to the buildings in which ideas were given form. Focus on a series of works by architects such as M.-J. Peyre and C. De Wailly, E.-L. Boullee and C.-N. Ledoux.

course.course_name: Robert Adam and the Architecture of the Late 18th Century In Britain
course.course_description: The work in architecture of Robert Adam and his brothers in the social, political, and aesthetic contexts of 18th-century England and in relation to that of their rivals and imitators, architects such as William Chambers, Henry Holland, and the Wyatts.

course.course_name: Jacques-Louis David: Art, Virtue and Revolution
course.course_description: Prerequisite: reading knowledge of French. Exploration of the relationship between art and political engagement through the career of Jacques-Louis David.

course.course_name: Identities and Resistances in Contemporary Non-Western Architecture
course.course_preface: Junior & Senior Art History Majors and Art History and GSAPP Graduate Students only. Limited Enrollment.
course.course_description: Junior & Senior Art History Majors and Art History and GSAPP Graduate Students only. Limited Enrollment. The proposed course is a critical introduction to the issues and personalities that are shaping the built environment today in much of the postcolonial, non-Western world. It is a cultural approach to the architecture, urban planning and design produced in Asia, the Middle East, North Africa and certain countries of Latin America.

course.course_name: History and Modernity In 19th Century Art
course.course_description: Selected problems in nineteenth-century art, with an emphasis on work before 1870.
course.prerequisites: Junior or senior art history majors or concentrators, and graduate students only.

course.course_description: Self-defined feminist artistsÂ’ practices since the 1960s, examined in relation to changing feminist theories: the alleged split between essentialist body-based feminism of the 1970s and the theorizing of gender in the 1980s as a cultural construction; the return to the body in the feminist art works and theory of the 1990s; feminism and radical politics; modernism and avant-garde strategies of social and political engagement.

course.course_name: Feminist Theory and Art Practices, 1960s - Present
course.course_description: Self-defined feminist artists’ practices since the 1960s,  in relation to changing feminist theories: essentialist body-based feminism of the 1970s; the 1980s theorizing of gender as a cultural construction; the return to the body in the 1990s; the women's movement and radical politics; feminist art, modernism, postmodernism, and avant-garde strategies of engagement; the current state of art world feminism.

The adjudged authenticity of a work of art is fundamental in determining its value as a commodity on the art market or, for example, in property claim disputes or in issues of cultural property restitution.  Using case studiesï¿½some straightforward and others extremely vexing--this course examines the many ways in which authenticity is measured through the use of provenance and art historical research, connoisseurship, and forensic resources.  From within the broader topics, finer issues will also be explored, among them, the hierarchy of attribution, condition and conservation, copies and reproductions, the period eye and the style of the marketplace.

This course examines the avant-garde art of the fifties and sixties, including assemblage, happenings, pop art, Fluxus, and artists' forays into film. It will examine the historical precedents of artists such as Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Allan Kaprow, Andy Warhol, Claes Oldenburg, Carolee Schneemann and others in relation to their historical precedents, development, critical and political aspects.
Survey of the histories and theories of landscape in art from the 18th to the 20th centuries, with a focus on 19th-century Europe.

course.course_name: Proseminar: Introduction To the Study of Art History
course.course_description: Required course for first-year PhD Students in the Art History Department
The history of calligraphy from earliest times through the Song dynasty, with special emphasis on the interaction of the state and the innovations of individual calligraphers.

course.course_name: Copies, Replicas, and Allusions in Chinese Art
course.course_description: Please note, this course will run from March 23- April 30, 2007.An examination of how artists in China have copied, imitated, and alluded to earlier works of art. Topics include the role of tracings and rubbings in the transmission of calligraphy, copying in pedagogy and workshop practice, the tradition of fang or creative imitation in painting, and the use of allusions and appropriation in contemporary Chinese art.

In what ways does the existence of a Â‘contemporary artÂ’ or contemporary situation in art require us to rethink the very idea of Â‘modernÂ’ (or Â‘postmodernÂ’) art, its methods and its geographies? In this lecture we take Mainland China as a focus and laboratory for this question, at once critical and curatorial. We look back to the peculiarities of the Â‘modernÂ’ period (since the Boxer Rebellion), the intellectual debates about modernity, the Cultural Revolution and its current aftermath. We examine a current sinological surrounding the nature and fate of Â‘traditionalÂ’ Chinese painting and look at the problem of urbanism in contemporary work. In the process, we examine a series of methodological questions involved in the study of a Â‘contemporary Chinese artÂ’ with the participation of historians, curators, and critics working in this emerging field. Related lectures and events in New York are suggested. The Seminar is open to qualified students in different disciplines and departments.

The goals of this course are to study major works of painting from the Song dynasty (960-1279) and to master art historical and sinological methods that can be used for research in any field of Chinese art. Among the topics that will receive special attention are the rise of landscape painting, imperial patronage, urban life and painting, the art of scholar-officials, and the relationship between words and images, especially during the Southern Song period.

course.course_name: Painting and Calligraphy in the Northern Song Dynasty
course.course_description: An examination of painting during the Northern Song period (960-1127), with special emphasis on issues of patronage, the relationship between words and images, the ritual uses of painting, and the relationship between pictorial style and visual experience.

course.course_name: Eccentricity and Sinophilia in Edo Period Painting
course.course_description: An examination of Japanese painting of the Edo period (1603-1868) that investigates major texts and modern studies of such artists as Ike Taiga and Itō Jakuchū, and considers how the social background, personal networks, religious faith, and literary expertise of painters found expression in their art. Using Tsuji Nobuo's Kisō no keifu (The Lineage of Eccentricity) and more recent publications in western languages as a guide for weekly discussions, the course will concentrate on painters active in mid-Edo period (late 17th-18th century) Kyoto and Edo.

This course explores the narrative handscroll (emaki), a major form of Japanese pictorial art, from its origins in the eighth century through the sixteenth century. Through an investigation of such masterworks as the "Illustrated Scrolls of the Tale of Genji," "Illustrated Legends of Mount Shigi," and "Life of Saint Ippen" (Ippen hijiri-e), the course will address questions of text-image relationships, patronage, and viewing practices in visual depictions of classical literature, hagiographic narratives, and popular tales. Although emphasis will be given to works for which texts and scholarly studies are available in English, reading ability in Japanese is recommended.

course.course_name: Japanese Arts of the Momyama Period
course.course_description: An investigation of the visual arts of the Momoyama period (1573-1615), Japan's era of political unification. This course will focus on the patronage and participation of provincial warlords in the production of gilded screen and panel paintings, lacquer, ceramics, and textiles. We will also consider the question of how Momoyama period aesthetics would have a lasting impact on all succeeding periods of Japanese art.

The course is related to the emergence of art related to Buddhism, commencing with emperor Asoka's (3rd century B.C.E.) rock and pillar edicts erected from Kandahar in Afghanistan to Amaravati in South India. Focus on the vibrantly carved stupa complexes constructed and decorated between the 1st century B.C.E. and the 5th century C.E., the many cave monastery complexes, with their rich sculpted and painted decoration, and the image of the Buddha.

course.course_name: Making the Gods: Divine Images in Ancient Greece
course.course_description: There are a relatively large number of monographic studies on iconographic and iconological aspects of various ancient Greek divinities’ imagery, Greek divine images as a general both religious and artistic category, however, have never before been studied from an art historical perspective. In addition, books published so far with a more comprehensive approach on statues of Greek gods have a clearly exclusive historical or philological character. The course aims at filling this rather strange gap in scholarship and will be based on a monograph on the subject currently under preparation (to appear with Harvard University Press). Although specific case studies will be discussed en detail whenever necessary, ancient Greek divine images will be studied with a more comprehensive approach, which will certainly avoid a Darwinian model of development and evolution in the visual construction of the divine in ancient Greece, usually found in introductory books on Greek art. Greek divine images will be presented within both their own historical context (literary appreciation and criticism, philosophical rejection, political use and abuse of the divine image) and a more wide-ranging set of questions raised by current art historical, anthropological, and philosophical theories about the significance of the image in general and the religious image in particular.
Italians, Etruscans, and the development of Roman art from the early republic to Augustus.

course.course_name: Roman Art II: Augustus To the Flavians
course.course_description: Roman art from Augustus to the end of the 1st century CE: the creation of an imperial art.

course.course_name: Roman Art III: From Trajan To Constantine
course.course_description: Some knowledge of Antiquity and German useful. Roman art from Trajan to Constantine; examination of Roman figural art, painting, mosaic, sculpture, their principal modes and themes of representation, and an analysis of the phenomenon of Late Antiquity

This lecture course is intended to confront art and architecture from the third through the sixth century among the peoples of the Roman Empire in its eastern and western forms. The two faculty, one specializing in secular and Jewish art, the other in Christian, provide a conversation about how traditional Roman art forms and ideas interact with new ones to create a distinct art versus one that is merely transitional or decadent. The lectures will be combined with talks from visitors and museum trips in order to keep the actual objects under scrutiny.

course.course_name: British Architectural Theory In the 19th Century
course.course_description: The reading of a series of books and lectures by architects and critics who effectively developed a theory of architecture that served as a springboard for radical theories of the 20th century.

Lectures on the art of Titian and its resonance, the position of the artist and his achievement within a Venetian context and beyond. Topics will include: issues of style and technique, the development of oil painting and a pittura di macchia; the altarpiece; religious narrative; mythological narrative; portraiture; the graphic arts and printing in Venice; TitianÂ’s circle of friends (Aretino and Sansovino); patterns of patronage; politics and religion; TitianÂ’s legacy.

This graduate-level lecture course addresses the key themes, operations, sites, and artists that inform current critical and aesthetic debates while grounding students in the history and theory that undergirds those debates. Topics include: Expanded Cinema and Structural Film, real-times and non-places, multi-screen environments and control, the obsolescence of film, medium-specificity and platform agnosticism, exhibiting and preserving projected images, and case studies on Hollis Frampton, Peter Kubelka, Stan Douglas, Harun Farocki, Anthony McCall, and others.   Each session will include an in-class screening, lecture, and short discussion.
The influence of older European art, as well as of oriental, tribal, popular, and naive art, on the work of modern artists from Cézanne to Mondrian.
The discourse on Modernism in the visual arts examined in relation to the theoretical positions of structuralism and post-structuralism, specifically the work of Roland Barthes and Jacques Derrida.

comparative approach to the vibrant contemporary arts outside the West which seem not to fit easily into current classifications. The aim is to initiate the discourse for the study of modern art and architecture in the countries of Asia, Africa, and the Americas.

At the center of the avant-garde imagination—and the interwar period in Europe more broadly—were photography, film, and other technological media. Long relegated to the margins of art history and rarely studied together, photography and film were often the guiding lights and vehicles for mass dissemination of avant-garde images and techniques. This lecture course delves into interbellum art, photography, film, and critical writing as it surveys a range of avant-garde movements and national cinemas; seminal artists and theorists; and topics such as montage, abstraction, advertising, sites of reception, and the arrière-garde.
